title: Cardiorespiratory Fitness and Longevity
content: The longevity benefits from greater cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and greater muscle mass and strength are discussed. A rapid increase in morbidity and mortality risk as fitness levels decline with age is shown in the literature. The relative contributions of CRF, muscle mass, and strength are also examined. The impact of fasting on muscle mass, the potential tradeoffs to consider, and the critical importance of working to maintain muscle mass and strength as we age are also discussed.

title: VO2 Max and Cardiorespiratory Fitness
content: VO2 max and its association with cardiorespiratory fitness is discussed. VO2 max is a measure of the maximum amount of oxygen a person can utilize during intense exercise. It is a common measure of cardiorespiratory fitness. The fittest of the fit have a VO2 max north of 80 milliliters of oxygen per kilogram per minute.

title: Mortality Risk and Cardiorespiratory Fitness
content: The changing mortality risk based on VO2 max and cardiorespiratory fitness is discussed. A clear trend is observed with all-cause mortality and fitness levels. The biggest gap is between people in the bottom 25% of fitness levels and everyone above them. Improving from low to above average fitness can result in a 60% to 70% reduction in mortality.

title: Improving Cardiorespiratory Fitness
content: The profound impact of improving cardiorespiratory fitness is discussed. The goal is for people to have a VO2 max that is considered 'elite' for someone a decade younger. For example, if you're 55 and female, the goal would be to have a VO2 max greater than 47, which is what would be considered elite for someone in their 40s to 50s.

title: Training for Cardiorespiratory Fitness
content: A training protocol for improving cardiorespiratory fitness is discussed. This includes doing VO2 max specific training once a week and Zone 2 training. The VO2 max training involves doing two to four minute intervals at the highest level that can be maintained for that duration. This is typically done at a one-to-one ratio of work to recovery.

title: Age and Cardiorespiratory Fitness
content: The dramatic drop off in cardiorespiratory fitness with age is discussed. There is a precipitous fall in VO2 max in the elite category from the fifth to the sixth decade of life and onwards. This is due to a shift from Type II to Type I muscle fibers as we age. However, it is important to note that 'elite' in this context does not mean 'elite athlete', but rather refers to the top 2.5% of the general population in terms of fitness levels.

title: Cardiorespiratory Fitness vs Smoking
content: Having low cardiorespiratory fitness can be more detrimental to health than smoking. Improving fitness levels can significantly reduce the risk of death.

title: Understanding Sarcopenia
content: Sarcopenia refers to the loss of muscle mass and strength, which is a common aspect of aging. It is defined by low muscle mass, low muscle strength, and low physical performance. Aging can lead to low-grade inflammation, oxidative stress, impaired regenerative capacity, and impaired muscle protein synthesis. This results in the replacement of Type II muscle fibers with fat and connective tissue, leading to insulin resistance, less glucose disposal, and a greater tendency to diabetes.

title: Measuring Muscle Mass
content: Muscle mass can be measured using a CT scan or an MRI, but these methods are not practical due to the risk of radiation and cost. The gold standard today is Dual X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA), which provides an approximation of total muscle mass. Another common method is Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA), which measures fat mass and fat-free mass.

title: Sarcopenia Cut-off Points
content: The sarcopenia cut-off points are defined by muscle quantity and functional deficits. For men, the cut-off point is below 7.0 kilograms per meter squared, and for women, it is less than 5.5 kilograms per meters squared. Functional deficits are measured by grip strength and chair stand tests.

title: Mortality Risk Associated with Declining Muscle Mass and Strength
content: Low muscle mass and strength are associated with an increased risk of mortality. A meta-analysis found a 60% increase in the relative risk of death for people with sarcopenia compared to those without. However, low muscle strength was found to be more associated with increased risk for mortality than low muscle mass.

title: Muscle Size vs. Strength
content: Muscle strength appears to matter more than muscle size when it comes to mortality risk. People lose about 1-2% of their muscle mass per year after the age of 50, and the loss of strength might be even greater. Therefore, maintaining strength and cardiorespiratory fitness is crucial for health as one ages.

title: Muscle Strength and Mortality
content: Generally with time, every Kaplan-Meier curve moves down as you go to the right. But the weaker you are, the quicker it goes down. They took their strength metric and they normalized it by muscle size. They used actually CT cross-sectional area and then they used DEXA. But when you take that normalized unit of strength per CT area and you reduce that by 0.2 units, or DEXA reduced by 0.34 units, you are seeing an increase of 26% or a 39% increase in mortality, respectively. With reduction in grip strength, which was normalized by DEXA arm measurement, it’s at 23%. And all of these were statistically significant.

title: Cardiorespiratory Fitness and Muscular Strength on Mortality Risk
content: Evaluating the cumulative impact of cardiorespiratory fitness and muscular strength on mortality risk when put together. What does it mean to be both fit from a cardiorespiratory standpoint and a strength standpoint? Is there a case to be made for doing both? You’re basically looking at three groups, each of which has three sub groups in it. Major groups are by strength, low, medium, and high strength. Within each of them, is low, medium and high cardiorespiratory fitness.

title: Rising Incidence in Deaths from Falls
content: Peter says it’s “stunning” when you look at the increase in mortality we’ve seen over the past decade basically with respect to falls. From 2007 to 2016, a 10 year period, we saw the deaths per 100,000 in the United States as a result of falls go from about 46 to 60 (That’s a 30% increase). At this rate, by 2030, we’re going to see seven fall deaths every hour.

title: Fasting and Muscle Mass
content: People look at fasting and actually caloric restriction and say, “Is there a trade off here that I’m making between building muscle and preserving muscle and potentially fasting?” You are making a trade off. Anytime you are doing a prolonged fast, probably anything over a couple of days, you’re taking a catabolic hit. Now the question is, how much of a hit are you taking to muscle size versus muscle strength?

title: Maintaining Muscle Mass and Strength as We Age
content: A lot of people think that there’s a linear or gradual decline in muscle mass or muscle size as we age. The reality is that it’s a lot more staggered as you get into older age… if you’re injured or if you’re bedridden, for example, that accelerates the decline. Art De Vany often talks about “physiological headroom” which is basically just having a muscle reserve so that on a rainy day—which might mean you might get a disease or you might have an injury where you are going be incapacitated—that to have that muscle and reserve is really important.
